title: Gyárfás–Sumner conjecture
summary: In graph theory, the Gyárfás–Sumner conjecture asks whether, for every tree T {\displaystyle T} and complete graph K {\displaystyle K} , the graphs with neither T {\displaystyle T} nor K {\displaystyle K} as induced subgraphs can be properly colored using only a constant number of colors. Equivalently, it asks whether the T {\displaystyle T} -free graphs are χ {\displaystyle \chi } -bounded.[1] It is named after András Gyárfás and David Sumner, who formulated it independently in 1975 and 1981 respectively.[2][3] It remains unproven.[4]
